Definition: Block programming is a style where visual blocks represent pieces of the computer code that can be manipulated through various forms of user input.
A style of programming where the programming environment adapts as the user controls and manipulates visual elements on the screen to help the programmer know what to do.
A region in a visual editor that contains information about the code in the editor
A region in a visual editor that contains all of the lines of code in a user's program. The editor can be manipulated with the keyboard, the mouse, or through the block palette.
Pieces of information sent to an action that provides it information on how to act.
